comments.text:
+WubDub88 You are most likely referring to the "Second" Orsinium in the 
Third Era. The one that Gortwog gro-Nagorm formed before the events of 
TESII: Daggerfall.

Here's the 2 sources for that Orsinium being sacked yet again by Bretons & 
Redguards in 4E11-15.

*An Elder Scrolls Novel: Lord of Souls*

A female Orc Legionnaire by the name of "Mazgar" recounts the tale of the 
sacking of Orsinium in 4E11, when she was just 7 years old.  Her mother was 
killed, but not before killing thirty invading Bretons/Redguards.

The Seventh and the Fifteenth Imperial Legions arrived & prevented the 
utter destruction of Orsinium at the hands of the Bretons and Redguards, 
leading the Orc survivors to Skyrim.

Mazgar's quote from the book, remembering the trek from the sacked Orsinium 
to the mountains in Skyrim as: "...terror, the chaos, the walk that went on 
for weeks through bitter cold—and never having enough to eat."

*Loading Screen Dialogue in Skyrim:* 

"Orcs, also known as Orsimer, are natives of Orsinium, a small mountain 
kingdom between Hammerfell and Skyrim. It has been sacked and rebuilt many 
times."

Presumably, some Orc NPCs also talk about this as the reason for there 
being Orc Strongholds in Skyrim.

(EDIT):

+WubDub88 +Motoko Hammond

Other than all that, there is no real mention of Orsinium being rebuilt in 
the 4th Era.

comments.text:
+Motoko Hammond You're welcome for the corrections.

As for the point on Ulfric Stormcloak...it may be incredibly difficult for 
him to "befriend" the Reachmen at this point.

In 4E174, after Imperial Legion soldiers were recalled to Cyrodiil to fight 
in the Great War, the Reachmen had swiftly retaken their homeland & 
occupied the city of Markarth in a surprisingly peaceful 2-year rule.

http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Lore:The_Bear_of_Markarth

http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Lore:The_%22Madmen%22_of_the_Reach

...Until Ulfric and his forces, called by Jarl Hrolfdir in 4E176, decided 
to "reclaim Nordic land" as well as kill any and all who opposed his idea 
of establishing Markarth as a sanctuary for open Talos-worship.  The 
Imperials, concerned with maintaining peace & order, had no choice but to 
give Ulfric what he wanted.

It is even mentioned that the Imperials attempted to peacefully recognize 
the Reach as an independent kingdom before Ulfric's "quelling" of them.

As of 4E201, Ulfric's Stormcloak-supporters (the Silver-Bloods) in Markarth 
have subjugated & imprisoned a certain number of Reachmen in Cidhna 
Mine...not even allowing these Reachmen "savages" to worship their own gods.

(Edit): Long story short...Ulfric's actions (as well as those of his 
followers) may have cost Skyrim any chances of peaceful reconciliation 
between Nords & Reachmen.

top_comment.text:
Many factual inaccuracies here: the forsworn are reachmen and not bretons: 
they are cousins of the bretons who have been influenced also by the orcs 
and nords and have developed a unique culture as a result. Secondly, there 
is no evidence that they drove all the nords from Markarth: the only 
evidence that we have on this matter suggests that only the most brutal 
nord landowners as well as the Jarl were executed. The Jarl's son Igmund 
for instance wasn't killed despite being nord royalty. Finally, they don't 
wage war against 'nords and non-bretons' but rather anyone who supports the 
nord occupiers (which is why they tend to target merchants who fund the 
growth of the nord state in the Reach): one of their members for instance 
is an orc.﻿

comments.text:
+Olórin356 This isn't quite the kind of thread for Imperial/Stormcloak 
debate, but whatevz.

*_________________*

Because the Stormcloaks would be totally by themselves *if* they win the 
Civil War in that highly-unlikely outcome.

If Ulfric wins *quickly and decisively*, he is a greater threat.

If the Civil War drags on, and both sides waste their resources fighting 
each other more & more, the whole Aldmeri Dominion (not just the Thalmor) 
gains an even greater advantage than they already had.

The Stormcloaks will not be a threat because of all these factors combined:

1. The damage caused by the pointless & unnecessary Civil War.

2. Continued Forsworn hostilities in the Reach.

3. Lack of support from other Provinces.  Morrowind, High Rock, & 
Hammerfell would undoubtedly all refuse to aid Skyrim (for very different 
reasons).

4. Because *one* large Dominion army (much larger than the detachment sent 
to Hammerfell) managed to fight the Empire, which included Skyrim's Nords, 
to a stalemate.

5. The Aldmeri Dominion's forces have been recovering their strength since 
4E176.   An Independent Skyrim can only start rebuilding in 4E201 or 
later...and I doubt the Dominion would give Skyrim a chance to recover, as 
in Stormcloak-victory it is no longer an Imperial Province that they can't 
legally invade.

6. The Dragonborn player-character will *not* be around to help them, 
considering how all player-characters ("Heroes") from past games have only 
'canonically' been involved in the Main Quests, and have disappeared off 
the face of Tamriel sometime after.

Stormcloak-controlled Independent Skyrim will not stand a chance.

comments.text:
+Beautiful Banjo Tiber Septim didn't conquer Hammerfell. In fact it wasn't 
the Imperial invasion that lead Hammerfell to joining the Empire, but the 
civil war going on. He was promised some land in exchange for helping the 
Forebears. The rebellion was won thanks to the tactics of Admiral Richton 
and Tiber Septim's dragon. Then when the Imperials attempted to impose 
complete control, the Redguards fought back and forced Tiber Septim to sign 
a treaty that favored them both. If anything Hammerfell kicked his ass and 
even when he joined that civil war the Crown was still able to hold him 
back. They joined the Empire, they weren't conquered. 

And after the Great War with the Thalmar, when the Emperor signed the White 
Gold Concordat, they left the Empire because they saw that they were 
unworthy to follow any longer. Now where some in Skyrim want to do the 
same, they're not able to agree where as the Redguards could. The 
resistance against the Thalmar is still strong in Hammerfell where as

happens, it benefits them and Skyrim will still be under their control.

top_comment.text:
Some problems.

1) No mention of the great Reachmen invasion of High Rock in the second era.
2) Worship of Hircine and Azura are conjectures. There is no information 
about what are the old gods. While I can agree that Hircine is a good 
guess. I can't see any connection with Azura. Malacath, Molag Bal or even 
Namira would be better guesses. Also "fan theory" they worship Lorkhan - 
the heartless god of the heartless warriors and Magnus also - old magic. 
3)  The Reachmen were a distinct group in the first era, so it's weird that 
you mention their genealogy right after taking this into 4th era. ﻿

comments.author: TheBrownViper

comments.text:
Not sure why you would expect them to not attack you because you're a 
Breton when they trouble High Rock as well, and they aren't even a Breton 
people (read lore discussions on reddit if you want to really want to 
circle jerk over what makes a Breton, a "modern" one I mean). They--the 
Reachmen--are an amalgamation of nearly every race in Tamriel, though many 
have Breton ancestry--the Forsworn are just a faction of the Reachmen by 
the way. They don't seek to drive out all non-Bretons from the Reach (they 
would have kicked out every non-Breton from Markarth when they captured it 
if that were their goal) when they have a history of trade and magical 
instruction with the Orcs. Source: Pocket to the Empire, 1st Ed./High Rock.

They want to return the Reach to Reachmen control, regardless of who is 
"invading". They were Bretons attacking non-Bretons for in-game purposes, 
which doesn't always reflect the lore.
comments.author: TheBrownViper

comments.text:
+Daniel Jones
Margret, the woman in the market, is an imperial spy. It's not the Forsworn 
who wants her dead. It's the Silver-Blood family, Ulfric's representatives 
in Markarth who orders the murder. Her death triggers the quest The 
Forsworn Conspiracy leading to the second quest, No One Escapes Cidhna 
Mine. During these quests you'll learn why the Forsworn are forced to obey 
the Silver-Blood family.

As you enter Karthwasten for the first time Silver-Blood mercenaries are 
shutting down the mine. Claiming they're there to protect it from the 
Forsworn. The owner claim they're real intention is to force him into 
selling the mine to the Silver-Bloods.

Knowing that the Silver-Blood can force the Forsworn to do their bidding 
and that they send "security forces" to "protect" mines having been 
attacked by the Forsworn...  are you sure they're terrorists and not acting 
on the behalf of the Silver-Blood family? Not saying they're saints, just 
don't take Skyrim at face value, there's often a twist.

The most important thing when considering to join the Forsworn is to 
remember that Bethesda has done little to make it a rewarding experience. 
If you're new to Skyrim, join a supported faction until you get the hang of 
console codes and basic modding. If you're comfortable with modding Skyrim 
and don't mind some extra work, go Forsworn. As far as politics goes the 
Nords have a good reason to fight being victims of religious persecution, 
the same applies to the Forsworn. Every faction has a sad story explaining 
how they ended up with blood on their hands. Join whatever side you like, 
as long as it's fun you're on the right side.

top_comment.text:
The parallels between the foresworn and the stormcloacks start to break 
down when you realize the reachmen cut out their hearts and sell them to 
evil witches. The reachman don't seem particularly intrested in 
establishing a stable government after their conquest. Ulfric is a 
romantic, but the foresworn are consumed by cynicism and revenge.﻿
top_comment.author: Brandon Stark

comments.text:
That remains to be seen. In the past, before Empress Hestra of Cyrodiil 
crushed them, they had ten independent kingdoms which were thriving. Who is 
to say these were dark or evil places? Almost all of their ancient culture 
was erased because the neighboring cultures feared and hated them. They 
couldn't be all bad, though, as they've managed to hold on to their 
identity and traditions for thousands of years. A completely anarchistic or 
destructive people wouldn't last that long. There is clearly something 
strong and enduring about the people in the Reach.
comments.author: Josh James

comments.text:
+onogrindsbrah Stoning women to death is persecution against a group of 
people against their consent. Wilfully cutting out your own heart and 
worshipping the 'old gods' is consensual, and nobody has a right to step in 
and prevent it just because it offends them.
comments.author: Tlevids

comments.text:
The reachmen are treated far far worse than the nords are: the nords are 
rebelling because one of their gods cannot now be worshipped in public 
while the reachmen are rebelling because their entire culture is being 
suppressed and they've been forced to the bottom of the economic pile. As a 
result, I'd expect the forsworn to fight more savagely. Also, they are 
interested in creating a stable government - they ruled Markarth for a few 
months before Ulfric's militia wreaked havoc on them.Furthermore, cutting 
out their own hearts and replacing them is a part of their culture and is 
consensual: not something we'd do, but it's their choice and the 
nords/Empire shouldn't forcibly prevent them from doing it just because 
they don't like it. I believe that the reachmen should rule the Reach as a 
separate province under the Empire.
comments.author: Tlevids

comments.text:
In any cultures where what you described happens, I merely consider those 
aspects to be unpalatable and even challengeable. However I am not arrogant 
enough to say that said culture is evil, neither am I arrogant enough to 
say that my culture is good.

I don't think you're arrogant enough to see the world in terms of good and 
evil either. We can both see things that disgust us.

Cultures can be criticised. In my view this must be done in a respectful 
and nuanced way. An entire cultural system shouldn't be demolished because 
of a few aspects that are deemed "abborant". Merely bring about the 
necessary change to remove those "abborant" aspects of said culture.
comments.author: Bobby Ranger

comments.text:
+Bobby Ranger There is right & wrong. moral, and cultural relativism makes 
educated people idiotic at times. stoning women to death for being raped is 
wrong. you can judge that, it is fine. I know this in the context of a 
videogame, but I see this in real life all the time when it comes to 
backwards cultures, and it annoys me to no end.
comments.author: onogrindsbrah

comments.text:
They seem like people trying to defend a land that is rightfully theirs.

I think killing anyone who enters their land is a bit drastic, but then 
again who am I to judge other cultures?

The whole giving hearts to Hagravens is strange but then again who am I to 
judge other cultures?

Morality is very subjective. Enforcing one's morality on other cultures is 
flat out wrong. If the Forsworn do not wish anyone to enter their land, 
best let them be. I don't think isolation is a beneficial idea, but I come 
from a culture where capital rules supreme. I come from a very narrow 
mindset. Perhaps I should be open to more mindsets.

The Forsworn are not good or evil. Just alien.

In short. Live and let live. If a person doesn't want you to enter their 
land, respect their wishes and do not be surprised if they are hostile 
towards you.
comments.author: Bobby Ranger

captions.text:
You've experienced the Elder Scrolls Series
in your own way, but want to learn more about

its story. Well, to get to the heart of the
story- you have to go back to the beginning...

They are described as either savage berserkers
swarming over the hills of the Reach with

war cries on their lips, or unseen anarchists
plotting terror in secret and striking from

the shadows. But what is actually known of
the group of insurgents known as the Forsworn?

Where have they come from? What do they want?
And how have they grown from a scattering

of defeated rebels to the highly organized
group of radicals they are today?

Millennia ago, in a part of the Reach known
then as the Sundered Hills, there was a child

born who prophecy said would be a warrior
without measure and a great ruler of men.

He was named Faolan; meaning Red Eagle.
The prophecy came to pass, and Faolan grew

to be a great leader who united what were
at the time the ten Kings of the Reach. Under

the banner of the Red Eagle, Faolan came to
be known far and wide for his courage and

ferocity in battle.
For a time, all was well, until Empress Hestra

of Cyrodil invaded the Reach in the name of
the Alessian Empire of Men; and one by one

the Kings of the Reach knelt in submission...or
were butchered, along with all those who stood

with them.
Still the Red Eagle would not surrender, and

over the years he gathered Reachmen who would
fight Hestra and her legions with stealth

and cunning. Yet for all the blows he struck
against the Empire's forces, more would

emerge to do battle. He fought with all he
had, and when he had no more left to give,

he cut out his own heart from his chest and
offered it to a Hagraven as a sacrifice in

return for the power to slay his enemies.
As a result, Faolan became a spirit of vengeance

and rained hell down on the Empire and her
people.

Wielding a great, flaming sword he faced Hestra
and her armies... and slew them all...

Over a thousand in a single day...
Ultimately the Red Eagle fell dead from his

wounds, but not before giving his mighty sword
to the people of the Reach along with a promise.

When the Reach was free of all foreign invaders,
he would arise and return to lead his people

once again...
Time went on, and the Reachman lingered until

the Great War of the Fourth Era. In the heat
of the conflict between the Empire under Titus

Mede and the Aldmeri Dominion, troops from
all across the land were summoned to fight.

This included most of the garrisons from the
Reach, stationed in the nearest city of Markarth.

For many centuries the native Bretons of High
Rock had intermarried with the Nords of Skyrim

and had in time created a unique bloodline
and culture with elements based on both Nord

and Breton principles yet truly belonging
to neither. There had been many disputes throughout

the years over the lucrative gold and silver
mines in the area known as the Reach, and

this hybrid race of Reachmen had grown to
hate the Nords. They considered them to be

invaders; stealing resources rightfully owned
by the "true sons and daughters of the Reach"

and were committed to purging the area of
all but themselves, even as they had millennia

ago, under the banner of the Red Eagle.
With most of the Imperial Guards of Markarth

diverted to battle with the forces of the
Thalmor, the city of Markarth was taken easily

by the fierce and brutal Reachmen who rebelled
from within the city walls and were quickly

joined by those from the surrounding areas.
The Reachmen drove the Nords away and would

hold the city for over two years, as the Great
War played out and the Empire was unable to

divert forces to deal with the uprising of
the indigenous people.

Enter Ulfric Stormcloak- Nordic son of Skyrim,
and a war hero besides. As newly appointed

Jarl of Windhelm, he was asked to assist with
the retaking of the city of Markarth by Jarl

Igmund. Ulfric and a militia of fighting men,
men who would soon be known as the Stormcloaks,

sacked the city in a bloody, brutal assault
that has come to be known as the infamous

Markarth Incident. The leader of the Reachmen,
Madanach, was captured, but not executed in

the belief he was worth more as a living hostage
than as a dead martyr.

The surviving Reachmen were driven into the
hills to be joined by other Bretons who had

witnessed the massacre or lost loved ones.
These Bretons bitterly decided to join the

hillmen to take arms against the murderous
invaders as their hero, Faolan the Red Eagle,

had before them.
The Forsworn are fiercely resolved to drive

all occupiers from what they feel are their
ancestral lands, and have become experts at

guerilla warfare and surprise terrorist attacks
designed to instill fear into the hearts of

the Nords and non-Bretons. The Forsworn continue
to be a real and very present threat in the

city of Markarth and its surrounding areas.
Organized into a collection of independent

cells, the Forsworn are believed to have infiltrated
the ranks of city dwellers by blending into

society in dress and conduct, as opposed to
their usual appearance of fur clad barbarians

wielding weapons made of bone and animal skin,
for the purpose of causing chaos and disarray

from within.
The Silver-blood family has taken particular

pains to root out the Forsworn and their operatives,
since their allegiance lies firmly with Jarl

Ulfric Stormcloak. There are many bounty hunters
who make their living solely by tracking down

Forsworn leaders and operatives and bringing
them to justice.

It is believed by some that the Forsworn have
retaliated by placing covert agents within

Silver-blood businesses and domestic staff,
waiting for an opportunity to decimate the

Silver-blood clan from within.
The fact that they have seamlessly integrated

themselves into the fabric of Markarth city
life is a sinister indication that at some

point another Markarth Incident could occur.
The Forsworn are sustained by a sort of religious

fervor, and worship several Daedric entities
known to them as Et'ada, or "Old Gods",

who scholars actually believe to be Azura
and Hircine the Hunter. Higher level Forsworn

have been rumored to sanctify themselves by
offering their actual hearts to their revered

hagravens in return for becoming a unstoppable
destructive force as had first been done by

Faolan. These arcane rituals are designed
to turn ordinary Forsworn into the personification

of vengeance or Briarhearts. The fearsome,
partly undead creatures are either melee fighters

or magic users, always male and always deadly.
While relatively small in number, their desire

to see all non-Bretons driven from the Reach
is fanatical and when combined with the powerful

magicks and weapons they have at their disposal,
enemies such as the Forsworn are a frighteningly

potent danger. With increasingly bolder and
deadlier attacks, they long for the day when

all those not of the Reach are dead or exiled,
so that Faolan, the fabled Red Eagle may once

again return to lead his people to prosperity
and greatness. Meanwhile, they strive to live

in harmony with the land their ancestors have
occupied for centuries untold. They hunt as

their forefathers did, in the spirit of one
of their primary deities, Hircine, whose feral

nature resonates with the untamed essence
of the Forsworn. The legend of the Daedric

Prince Hircine is the story of the hunt, and
of the savage beast that lies within the darkest

depths of the souls of all men.
But that- is a story for another day...

title: Elder Scrolls Lore: Forsworn of the Reach
